markdown_report:
1) Objective and constraints
- Field/length: Work over GF(13) with length n = 12. Fix the primitive element 2 ∈ GF(13)× (order 12) so the primitive 12th root of unity is α = 2, with α^j = 2^j for j = 0,…,11.
- Locality (r = 2): Enforce that the parity-check polynomial h(x) is divisible by L(x) = 1 + x^4 + x^8. This prescribes 3-term cyclic locality checks supported on arithmetic progressions with step 4 modulo 12.
- Dual/orthogonality: Require Euclidean self-orthogonality C ⊆ C^⊥. In defining-set language (gcd(n, q) = 1, singleton q-cyclotomic cosets), this is equivalent to Z(C) ⊇ Z_n \ (−Z(C)), or equivalently Z(C) ∪ (−Z(C)) = Z_n; in particular the fixed points 0 and, because n is even, 6 must lie in Z(C).
- Distance: A BCH-style designed-distance constraint may be invoked, but will be shown irrelevant given the two structural constraints above.
- Uniqueness/verifiability: The task culminates in an exact integer count. We show the constraints are inconsistent and the exact number of admissible codes is N = 0.
- Prohibited shortcuts: Do not place the locality factor into g(x); the locality factor must divide h(x) (dual side). Do not confuse Euclidean with Hermitian duality.

2) Problem statement
Let C be a cyclic code of length n = 12 over GF(13). Fix α = 2 ∈ GF(13) as a primitive 12th root of unity and represent exponents modulo 12. Let g(x) be the monic generator polynomial of C and h(x) = (x^12 − 1)/g(x) the monic parity-check polynomial.

Constraints:
(i) Locality: h(x) is divisible by L(x) = 1 + x^4 + x^8.
(ii) Euclidean self-orthogonality: C ⊆ C^⊥ over GF(13).
(iii) Designed-distance clause (BCH-type) may be used if needed but is not required to be explicitly stated in terms of consecutive exponents.

Question. Determine the exact number N of cyclic codes C (equivalently, of monic generator polynomials g(x) | x^12 − 1) satisfying (i)–(ii). Give N as a single integer.

3) Solution
Step 0. Preliminaries.
- Since 12 | (13 − 1), x^12 − 1 splits completely over GF(13) as ∏_{j=0}^{11} (x − α^j) with α = 2. Cyclotomic cosets modulo 12 under q = 13 are singletons, so defining sets Z ⊆ {0,…,11} correspond bijectively to cyclic codes via g(x) = ∏_{j∈Z} (x − α^j) and h(x) = ∏_{j∉Z} (x − α^j).
- Euclidean dual defining-set rule (semisimple case): Z(C^⊥) = Z_n \ (−Z(C)). Hence C ⊆ C^⊥ iff Z(C^⊥) ⊆ Z(C), i.e., Z ⊇ Z_n \ (−Z). Equivalently, Z ∪ (−Z) = Z_n and thus the fixed points 0 and 6 (since 6 ≡ −6) must belong to Z.

Step 1. Consequence of the locality divisibility L | h.
Factor x^12 − 1 = (x^4 − 1)(x^8 + x^4 + 1), so L(x) = 1 + x^4 + x^8 has as zeros exactly those 12th roots whose exponents are j ≡ 1,2 (mod 3). If L | h, then every zero of L is a zero of h; equivalently, those exponents cannot be zeros of g. In defining-set language, this forces
Z ⊆ {0,3,6,9}.
Indeed, Z is disjoint from S := {1,2,4,5,7,8,10,11}, so Z ⊆ S^c = {0,3,6,9}.

Step 2. Self-orthogonality contradicts the locality-imposed restriction.
Self-orthogonality requires Z ∪ (−Z) = Z_n. But if Z ⊆ {0,3,6,9}, then for the pair {1,11} neither 1 nor 11 can lie in Z, so 1 ∉ Z ∪ (−Z), violating Z ∪ (−Z) = Z_n. Therefore no defining set Z can simultaneously satisfy L | h and C ⊆ C^⊥.

Step 3. Role of BCH clause.
Any additional BCH-style distance requirement only further restricts admissible codes, so it cannot resolve the inconsistency. Therefore the feasible set is empty regardless of the designed-distance target.

Conclusion. The exact count of such codes is
N = 0.

4) Verification guidance
- Exhaustive algebraic check:
  1) Enumerate all subsets Z ⊆ {0,…,11}. Compute h implicitly via complements (zeros(h) = Z^c) or form g(x) = ∏_{j∈Z} (x − α^j) and h(x) = (x^12 − 1)/g(x).
  2) Locality test: L | h is equivalent here to Z ∩ S = ∅ with S = {1,2,4,5,7,8,10,11} (since zeros(h) must contain the zeros of L). An equivalent computational test is h mod L = 0 in GF(13)[x].
  3) Euclidean self-orthogonality test: verify Z ∪ (−Z) = Z_n (negation map i ↦ (12 − i) mod 12), and check that 0,6 ∈ Z.
  4) No subset will satisfy both tests; the count must be 0.
- Optional spectral cross-check: Compute the spectrum of L to confirm its zero set indices are S (j ≡ 1,2 mod 3). The condition L | h forces S ⊆ zeros(h), i.e., S ∩ Z = ∅; this immediately implies Z ⊆ {0,3,6,9} and contradicts self-orthogonality as above.
- Edge checks: confirm α = 2 has order 12 in GF(13); verify factorization x^12 − 1 = (x^4 − 1)(x^8 + x^4 + 1); check that 0 and 6 are self-inverse indices and thus mandatory for self-orthogonality.

Final answer: N = 0.

idea.description: Fuse a dual-side locality constraint L | h with Euclidean self-orthogonality via defining-set duality in the fully split regime n | (q−1). Over GF(13), n=12, L(x)=1+x^4+x^8 forces Z ⊆ {0,3,6,9}, while self-orthogonality requires Z ∪ (−Z) = Z_n (hence 0 and 6 in Z and every pair {i,−i} represented). These are incompatible, yielding a precise impossibility (count N=0).
idea.motivation: Combining locality through a specific dual factor and orthogonality through the exact defining-set relation creates a tight, nontrivial constraint system. The contradiction is not from rote BCH/RS patterns but from careful use of duality and factor/zero bookkeeping, resisting shortcut methods.
idea.implementation_notes: Fix α = 2 as the primitive 12th root in GF(13). Compute S = {j≡1,2 (mod 3)} as the zero-index set of L. Enforcing L | h is equivalent to Z ∩ S = ∅, hence Z ⊆ {0,3,6,9}. Euclidean self-orthogonality is tested by Z ∪ (−Z) = Z_n (so fixed points 0 and 6 must be in Z). Since Z ⊆ {0,3,6,9}, indices {1,11} violate the union condition, so no solution exists. Optional brute-force enumeration over all subsets Z ⊆ Z/12Z confirms zero solutions.
idea.pseudocode:
alpha = 2 mod 13
N = set(range(12))
S = {1,2,4,5,7,8,10,11}         # zeros of L(x) = 1 + x^4 + x^8
neg = lambda T: {(-i) % 12 for i in T}
count = 0
for Z in all_subsets(N):
    # locality test L | h  <=>  Z ∩ S = ∅
    if not Z.isdisjoint(S):
        continue
    # Euclidean self-orthogonality: Z ∪ (−Z) = N (in particular 0,6 ∈ Z)
    if (Z | neg(Z)) != N:
        continue
    count += 1
return count  # should be 0

originality.positive: Non-binary small-length cyclic setting with explicit primitive element and a specific dual-side locality factor; contradiction emerges only via precise dual-defining-set reasoning.
originality.negative: Relies on standard cyclic-code duality; novelty comes from the constraint fusion and exact impossibility statement.

future_potential.positive: Generalizes to other n | (q−1) and r+1-term dual checks, or to Hermitian duality/constacyclic variants to toggle feasibility; can generate satisfiable/unsatisfiable families with exact counts.
future_potential.negative: Requires careful parameter choices to avoid trivial contradictions or trivial satisfiable cases.

code_difficulty.positive: Enumeration over 2^12 subsets with simple set operations is straightforward; divisibility can be checked either via sets or polynomial arithmetic.
code_difficulty.negative: Precision is required to apply the correct self-orthogonality condition (Z ∪ (−Z) = Z_n). Mixing up reciprocal/negation or using the wrong orthogonality test can invalidate results.

pitfalls: Confusing zeros of g with zeros of h; the locality factor lies on the dual side (h), and L | h means Z ∩ zeros(L) = ∅.
Misapplying Euclidean vs Hermitian dual relations; here Euclidean gives Z(C^⊥) = Z_n \ (−Z(C)) and self-orthogonality requires Z ∪ (−Z) = Z_n (so 0 and 6 must be in Z).
Assuming L | h implies the coefficient vector of L itself lies in C^⊥; in general v ∈ C^⊥ iff h | v^* (for L self-reciprocal, h | L), not L | h.
Using characteristic 3 (q=3^m), where 1 + x^4 + x^8 degenerates; must keep q=13.

theorem_refs.name: Defining-Set Duality for Cyclic Codes (Euclidean)
theorem_refs.statement: Let C be a cyclic code of length n over GF(q) with gcd(n, q) = 1 and defining set Z ⊆ Z/nZ. Then C^⊥ is cyclic with Z(C^⊥) = Z/nZ \ (−Z), where −Z = {−i mod n : i ∈ Z}. In particular, C ⊆ C^⊥ iff Z ⊇ Z/nZ \ (−Z), i.e., Z ∪ (−Z) = Z/nZ; fixed points of inversion must be in Z.

theorem_refs.name: Mattson–Solomon Transform for Cyclic Codes
theorem_refs.statement: Evaluation at the n-th roots of unity α^i diagonalizes cyclic convolution: a cyclic code corresponds to sequences whose spectra vanish on a fixed index set T (the defining set). Factor/zero-set relations can be tracked via these spectra.
theorem_refs.source: Algebraic Codes for Data Transmission, Ch. on DFT-based codes
theorem_refs.notes: In the semisimple case (gcd(n, q) = 1), each cyclotomic coset is a singleton.

theorem_refs.name: Locality via ν-term Dual Checks
theorem_refs.statement: If the dual contains a weight-(r+1) vector v(x) = 1 + x^s + ⋯ + x^{rs}, with s = n/(r+1), then locality r follows. In our divisibility formulation, L | h constrains zeros(h) to include zeros(L), which already suffices to derive the contradiction with self-orthogonality.
theorem_refs.notes: Beware: v ∈ C^⊥ iff h | v^* (for self-reciprocal v, h | v), not v dividing h.

problem_pair.problem_text:
Work over GF(13). Let n = 12 and fix α = 2 ∈ GF(13) as a primitive 12th root of unity (so x^12 − 1 = ∏_{j=0}^{11} (x − α^j)). Let C be a cyclic code of length 12 with monic generator polynomial g(x) and parity-check polynomial h(x) = (x^12 − 1)/g(x).

Assume: (i) h(x) is divisible by L(x) = 1 + x^4 + x^8; (ii) C is Euclidean self-orthogonal (C ⊆ C^⊥) over GF(13).

Question. How many cyclic codes C (equivalently, monic divisors g(x) of x^12 − 1) satisfy (i) and (ii)? Give the exact integer N.
problem_pair.solution_text:
Let Z ⊆ {0,…,11} be the defining set of C: g(x) = ∏_{j∈Z} (x − α^j). Since 12 | (13 − 1), all cyclotomic cosets are singletons.

1) Locality divisibility L | h: the zeros of L are exactly indices S = {j : j ≡ 1,2 (mod 3)}. If L | h, then S ⊆ zeros(h), hence S ∩ Z = ∅ and thus Z ⊆ {0,3,6,9}.

2) Euclidean self-orthogonality is equivalent to Z ⊇ Z_n \ (−Z), i.e., Z ∪ (−Z) = Z_n; in particular 0 and 6 must lie in Z and for each pair {i, −i} at least one element must be in Z. But since Z ⊆ {0,3,6,9}, neither 1 nor 11 can lie in Z, so 1 ∉ Z ∪ (−Z), contradicting self-orthogonality.

Therefore no such C exists, and the number of admissible codes is N = 0.
prerequisites: Finite fields and roots of unity
Discrete Fourier transform over finite fields

verification_notes:
Two independent routes:
1) Brute-force enumeration: Iterate all subsets Z ⊆ {0,…,11}. Test locality via set avoidance (Z ∩ S = ∅ with S = {1,2,4,5,7,8,10,11}); test Euclidean self-orthogonality via Z ∪ (−Z) = Z_n (negation i ↦ (12 − i) mod 12) and confirm 0,6 ∈ Z. Count of hits must be 0. As a cross-check, construct g(x) = ∏_{j∈Z}(x − 2^j) and verify h mod L = 0.
2) Spectral/zero-set short-circuit: zeros(L) = S forces Z ⊆ {0,3,6,9}, which immediately violates Z ∪ (−Z) = Z_n because indices 1 and 11 are excluded from Z. Boundary checks: confirm 2 has order 12 in GF(13); verify x^12 − 1 = (x^4 − 1)(x^8 + x^4 + 1); check that 0 and 6 are self-inverse in Z/12Z.

feedback.message: The corrected dual-defining-set condition (self-orthogonality ⇔ Z ∪ (−Z) = Z_n) paired with the zero-set implication of L | h yields a clean contradiction, so the exact answer remains N = 0. The report now avoids the common pitfall that L | h would imply L’s vector lies in C^⊥ (the right criterion is h | L for that).
suggestions: If a non-empty family is desired, replace Euclidean self-orthogonality with LCD (C ∩ C^⊥ = {0}) or switch to Hermitian self-orthogonality over GF(13^2).
Alternatively, replace L by a weighted check 1 + a x^4 + a^2 x^8 with a a primitive cube root of unity to shift the forbidden zero set and recover feasibility.
For constructive instances, drop self-orthogonality and ask for the unique g(x) maximizing k subject to L | h and an explicit BCH designed distance.
